ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Has there been a time when you heard voices?
Has there been a time when you had visions or saw things that were not visible to others?

Has there been a time when you had beliefs or ideas that others did not share or later found out were not true like people being against you, people trying to harm you, or people talking about you, or believing you were being given special messages (e.g., through the TV or the Integer)?

Has there been a time when you have ever engaged in any unusual behavior, had speech that was mixed up or did not make sense (aside from mania and/or depression), or had your body stuck in one position so that you could not move?

Has there been a time when you have had many days in a row when you did not get dressed, or have felt you had nothing to say, or appeared to have no emotions or have inappropriate emotions? (aside from mania and/or depression)
Does the subject manifest or describe disorganized speech?
Does the subject manifest or describe bizarre behavior?

Does the subject manifest gross flattening of affect (e.g., unchanging facial expression, decreased spontaneous movements, poor eye contact, lack of vocal inflection) or poverty of content of speech (e.g., the patient's replies are adequate in amount but tend to be vague, over concrete or over generalized, and convey little in information)?
Did any of these symptoms last persistently throughout the day for one day or intermittently for a period of three days?
If yes to symptoms, please describe:
Are you currently experiencing (Psychotic symptoms)?
How long ago did this (Psychotic symptoms) begin? Days
How long ago did this (Psychotic symptoms) begin? Weeks
How old were you the last time you had (Psychotic symptoms)?
How long ago did this (Psychotic symptoms) begin? Days
How long ago did this (Psychotic symptoms) begin? Weeks
Since you first began experiencing (Psychotic symptoms) have you ever returned to your normal self for at least two months?
Persecutory Delusions: Have you ever felt that people were out to get you or deliberately trying to harm you?
Persecutory Delusions: If yes: Specify.
Jealousy Delusions: Have you ever been convinced that your (husband/wife/boyfriend/girlfriend) was being unfaithful to you?
Jealousy Delusions: What made you think so?
Guilt or Sin Delusions: Have you ever been convinced that you committed a crime, sinned greatly, or deserved punishment?
Grandiose Delusions: Have you ever felt you had any special powers, talents, or abilities much more than other people?
Religious Delusions: Have you had any religious beliefs or experiences that other people didn't share?
Religious Delusions: If yes: Specify.
Somatic Delusions: Have you ever had a change in your body or the way it was working for which the doctor could find no cause? (Probe: like incurable cancer, bowels stopped up, insides rotting?)
Somatic Delusions: If yes: Specify.
Erotomanic Delusions: Have you ever believed that another person was in love with you when there was no real reason to think so?

Delusions of Reference: Have you ever seen things in magazines or on TV that seem to refer specifically to you or contain a special message for you? Have you ever been sure that people were talking about you, laughing at you, or watching you?
Being Controlled: Have you ever felt you were being controlled or possessed by some outside force or person?
Thought Broadcasting: Have you ever felt your thoughts were broadcast so other people could hear them?
Thought Insertion: Have you ever felt that thoughts that were not your own were being put into your head by some outside force?
Thought Withdrawal: Have you ever felt your thoughts were taken out of your head by some outside force?
How long did your longest period of (Delusions) last? Days
How long did your longest period of (Delusions) last? Weeks
Were you convinced of these beliefs at the time?
INTERVIEWER: describe positive responses
When you believed any (Delusion) were you at all confused about where you were or the time of day? Did you have trouble with your memory?
Notes: 0= None: No distortion of subject's sensorium during delusional beliefs.; 1= Questionable; 2= Definite: Sensorium is clouded, due to medication, substance use, or general medical condition.; 3= Definite: Clouded sensorium, but not due to medication, substance use, or general medical condition.; 9= Unknown: No information.

ElementDescription: Rate Fragmentary Nature of Delusions.
Notes: 0= Not at all: All delusions are around a single theme, such as persecution.; 1= Somewhat fragmentary: Several different, but possibly related themes.; 2= Definitely fragmentary: Unrelated themes.; 9= Unknown

ElementDescription: Rate Widespread Delusions.
Notes: 0= Not widespread.; 1= Widespread: Delusions intrude into most aspects of patient's life and/or preoccupy patient most of the time.; 9= Unknown

ElementDescription: Rate Bizarre Quality of Delusions.
Notes: 0= Not at all: (e.g., wife is unfaithful).; 1= Somewhat bizarre: (e.g., subject is being persecuted by witches).; 2= Definitely bizarre: (e.g., little green men from Mars have been recording his dreams and broadcasting them back home).; 9= Unknown

ElementDescription: Auditory (Voices, Noises, Music): Have you ever heard sounds or voices other people could not hear?
Auditory (Voices, Noises, Music): Did they say bad things about you or threaten you?
Auditory (Running Commentary): Have you ever heard voices that described or commented on what you were doing or thinking?
Auditory (Two or More Voices):Have you ever heard two or more voices talking with each other?
Thought Echo: Have you ever experienced hearing your thoughts repeated or echoed?
Somatic or Tactile: Have you ever had unusual sensations or other strange feelings in your body when there was nothing to account for them?
Olfactory: Have you ever experienced any strange smells you couldn't account for or smells that others didn't notice?
Visual: Have you ever had visions or seen things that other people could not?
Visual: Did this only occur when you were falling asleep or waking up?
Gustatory: Have you ever had a strange taste in your mouth that you couldn't account for?
How long did your longest period of (Hallucinations) last? Days
How long did your longest period of (Hallucinations) last? Weeks

Did the subject experience prominent hallucinations (throughout the day for several days or several times a week for several weeks, each hallucination experience not being limited to a few brief moments)?
Rate Sensorium While Hallucinating: When you were (Hallucinating) were you at all confused about where you were or the time of day? did you have trouble with your memory?
Notes: 0= None: No distortion of subject's sensorium during hallucination.; 1= Questionable; 2= Definite: Sensorium is clouded, due to medication, substance use, or general medical condition.; 3= Definite: Clouded sensorium, but not due to medication, substance use, or general medical condition.; 9= Unknown: No information.

ElementDescription: Check if subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories: Delusions
Check if subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories: Definitely bizarre delusions
Check if subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories: Hallucinations
Check if subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories: Two or more voices or a voice that commented on what you were doing or thinking
Check if subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories: Disorganized speech (e.g. frequent derailment or incoherence)
Check if subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories: Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
Check if subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories: Negative symptoms, i.e., affective flattening, alogia or avolition
Total Score: reported symptoms in each of the following categories
Notes: sum (digs_schizo_del, digs_schizo_del_yes, digs_schizo_hal, digs_schizo_hal_yes, digs_schizo_spe, digs_schizo_dis_beh, digs_schizo_neg_sym)

ElementDescription: Has the subject ever had symptoms from two or more of the above categories most of the time for at least one month, or been treated successfully for symptoms occurring together from two or more of these categories?
Has the subject ever had most of the time for a month or been treated successfully for either of these?
Was there ever a period of time when you had (Psychotic symptoms) when you were not feeling (depressed/high or excited)?
Did these symptoms ever last as long as one week while you were not (depressed/high)?
How long did you have these symptoms when you were not (depressed/high)? Days
How long did you have these symptoms when you were not (depressed/high)? Weeks
Review all psychotic symptoms coded present during depression and code YES if mood incongruent psychotic symptoms were present during major depression.
How old were you the first time that you were experiencing (describe delusions, hallucinations, or other criteria for schizophrenia noted by the subject previously)?
How long did those (Psychotic symptoms) last? Days
How long did those (Psychotic symptoms) last? Weeks
Did you return to feeling like your normal self for at least two months?
How many episodes have you had?
Do you suspect autism on the basis of the medical history section or other information?
Do you suspect another Pervasive Developmental Disorder on the basis of the medical history section or other information?
During the current/most recent episode, have you also been experiencing a low/depressive episode?
During the current/most recent episode, have you also been experiencing a high/manic episode?
Did the current/most recent episode follow increased or excessive use of alcohol?
If yes to alcohol use: Specify:
Did the current/most recent episode follow use of street drugs?
If yes to street drug use: Specify:
Did the current/most recent episode follow serious medical illness?
If yes to serious medical illness: Specify:
Did the current/most recent episode follow use of prescription medications?
If yes to prescription medication use: Specify:
Did the current/most recent episode follow an extremely stressful life event (such as your house burning down or a violent death of a family member or friend)?
If yes to stressful life events: Specify:
During the current/most recent episode, was there a change in your ability to function at work or with family and friends?
Has this change in your functioning continued for much of the time since this episode began?
DSM III-R Brief Reactive Psychosis: During the current/most recent episode, did you experience unpredictable, intense mood changes or did you feel baffled?
If FEMALE: Did the current/most recent episode begin within four weeks of childbirth?
Prodromal Period: During that time did you stay away from family and friends, become socially isolated?
Prodromal Period: During that time did you have trouble doing your job, going to school, or doing your work at home?
Prodromal Period: During that time did you do anything unusual, like collecting garbage, talking to yourself in public, hoarding food?
Prodromal Period: During that time did you neglect grooming, bathing, and keeping your clothes cleaned?
Prodromal Period: During that time did you appear to have no emotions or show emotions that did not fit with what was going on (for example, giggle or cry at the wrong time)?
Prodromal Period: During that time did you speak in a way that was hard to understand, have a hard time getting to the point, or were you at a loss for words (not due to a speech impediment)?

Prodromal Period: During that time did you have unusual beliefs or magical thinking (e.g., superstitiousness, belief in clairvoyance, telepathy, sixth sense, feeling that "others can feel my feelings"), have ideas that were not quite true, think others were referring to you when they really were not?

Prodromal Period: During that time did you have unusual visual experiences or experiences of hearing (e.g., whispers, crackling), sense the presence of a force or person not actually there, or feel the world is unreal?
Prodromal Period: During that time did you have trouble getting going, or have no interests or energy?

Prodromal Period: During that time did you think that things around you, such as TV programs or newspaper articles, had some special meaning just for you, or think people were talking about you or laughing at you, or think you were receiving special messages in other ways?
Prodromal Period: During that time did you get nervous about being around other people, or about going to parties or other social events, or take criticism badly?
Prodromal Period: During that time did you worry that people had it in for you, or feel that most people were your enemies, or think people were making fun of you?
Prodromal Period: How long did you have these experiences before you had (Active psychotic features)?
Prodromal Period: Was this year typical of your usual self (that is, as subject was prior to onset of earliest symptoms)?
Residual Period: During that time did you stay away from family and friends, become socially isolated?
Residual Period: During that time did you have trouble doing your job, going to school, or doing your work at home?
Residual Period: During that time did you do anything unusual, like collecting garbage, talking to yourself in public, hoarding food?
Residual Period: During that time did you neglect grooming, bathing, and keeping your clothes cleaned?
Residual Period: During that time did you appear to have no emotions or show emotions that did not fit with what was going on (for example, giggle or cry at the wrong time)?
Residual Period: During that time did you speak in a way that was hard to understand, have a hard time getting to the point, or were you at a loss for words (not due to a speech impediment)?

Residual Period: During that time did you have unusual beliefs or magical thinking (e.g., superstitiousness, belief in clairvoyance, telepathy, sixth sense, feeling that "others can feel my feelings"), have ideas that were not quite true, think others were referring to you when they really were not?

Residual Period: During that time did you have unusual visual experiences or experiences of hearing (e.g., whispers, crackling), sense the presence of a force or person not actually there, or feel the world is unreal?
Residual Period: During that time did you have trouble getting going, or have no interests or energy?

Residual Period: During that time did you think that things around you, such as TV programs or newspaper articles, had some special meaning just for you, or think people were talking about you or laughing at you, or think you were receiving special messages in other ways?
Residual Period: During that time did you get nervous about being around other people, or about going to parties or other social events, or take criticism badly?
Residual Period: During that time did you worry that people had it in for you, or feel that most people were your enemies, or think people were making fun of you?
Residual Period: How long did you have these experiences after your (Active psychotic features) stopped?
Residual Period: Did you return to your usual self (as subject was prior to age of onset of earliest symptoms)?
Mania: Did (Delusions or Hallucinations) ever occur when you were feeling extremely good or high, or when you were feeling unusually irritable?
Mania: If yes to (Delusions or Hallucinations) ever occur: Record response:
Mania: Did the (Delusions or Hallucinations) correspond to either of the manic episodes described previously?
Mania: Specify and code whether subject's mood was:
Notes: 1= Only irritable; 2= Euphoric (with or without irritability)

ElementDescription: Mania: During the period of feeling especially good or high when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Overactivity: Running around, many projects, or physically agitated?

Mania: During the period of feeling especially good or high when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? More talkative than usual, speech pressured?

Mania: During the period of feeling especially good or high when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Thoughts racing, jumping from topic to topic?

Mania: During the period of feeling especially good or high when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Feeling grandiose: more important, special, powerful?

Mania: During the period of feeling especially good or high when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Needing less sleep: energetic after little or no sleep?

Mania: During the period of feeling especially good or high when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Attention distracted by unimportant things?

Mania: During the period of feeling especially good or high when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Doing risky things for pleasure: spending, sex, reckless driving, etc.?
Mania: Enter number of definite symptoms.
Mania: Did these episodes only follow alcohol or drug intake or withdrawal?
Mania: Has the subject ever met Criterion A for schizophrenia?
Mania: Did subject ever meet Criterion A for schizophrenia during an episode of mania?
Mania: Subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories during the episode of mania: Delusions
Mania: Subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories during the episode of mania: Bizarre delusions
Mania: Subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories during the episode of mania: Hallucinations
Mania: Subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories during the episode of mania: Two or more voices or a voice commenting on the subject's behavior or thoughts
Mania: Subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories during the episode of mania: Disorganized speech (e.g. frequent derailment or incoherence)
Mania: Subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories during the episode of mania: Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
Mania: Subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories during the episode of mania: Negative symptoms, i.e., affective flattening, alogia or avolition

Mania: Presence of Mood Incongruent Psychotic Symptoms: Code YES if psychotic symptoms occurring during any manic episode had content that was not consistent with themes of inflated worth, power, knowledge, identity, or special relationship to a deity or a famous person.
Mania: Persistence of Psychotic Symptoms with Affective Clearing: Did the (Hallucinations/delusions) ever continue after your mood returned to normal?
Mania: Persistence of Psychotic Symptoms with Affective Clearing: What is the longest time they lasted after your mood became normal?
Mania: Did the (Other psychotic symptoms such as formal thought disorder, bizarre behavior, catatonia) ever continue after your mood returned to normal?
Mania: What is the longest time they lasted after your mood became normal?
Mania: Were the Affective syndromes brief relative to the Psychotic symptoms?
Depressed: Did (Delusions or Hallucinations) ever occur when you were feeling especially depressed?
Depressed: If yes to (Delusions or Hallucinations) ever occur: Record response:
Depressed: Did the (Delusions or Hallucinations) correspond to either of the depressive episodes described previously?

Depressed: During the period of feeling especially depressed when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Diminished desire for food, or marked overeating?

Depressed: During the period of feeling especially depressed when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Inability to sleep when sleep was desired, or excessive sleep?
Depressed: During the period of feeling especially depressed when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Feeling slowed down?
Depressed: During the period of feeling especially depressed when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Having fatigue or a loss of energy?

Depressed: During the period of feeling especially depressed when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Losing interest in pleasurable activities?
Depressed: During the period of feeling especially depressed when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Feeling guilty or worthless?

Depressed: During the period of feeling especially depressed when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Being unable to think or retain written information?

Depressed: During the period of feeling especially depressed when you were also having (Psychotic symptoms) were you also experiencing any of these symptoms? Feeling suicidal or thinking a lot about death?

Depressed: Is this a current episode?
Depressed: Did these episodes only follow alcohol or drug intake or withdrawal?
Depressed: Has the subject ever met Criterion A for schizophrenia?
Depressed: Did subject ever meet Criterion A for schizophrenia during an episode of depression?

Depressed: Subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories during the episode of Depressed: Bizarre delusions
Depressed: Subject has reported symptoms in each of the following categories during the episode of Depressed: Hallucinations

Polydypsia: Have you ever consumed excess fluids over an extended period of time such that you had problems of low sodium, seizures, confusion, urinary tract difficulties, or other medical complications?
Pattern of Symptoms INTERVIEWER: Choose appropriate pattern from descriptions below:
Notes: 1= Continuously Positive; 2= Predominantly Negative; 3= Predominantly Positive Converting to Predominantly Negative; 4= Negative Converting to Positive; 5= Continuous Mixture of Positive and Negative Symptoms

ElementDescription: Classification of Longitudinal Course for Schizophrenia: INTERVIEWER: Choose appropriate pattern from descriptions below:
Notes: 1= Episodic With Interepisode Residual Symptoms; 2= Episodic With No Interepisode Residual Symptoms; 3= Continuous; 4= Single Episode in Partial Remission; 5= Single Episode in Full Remission; 6= Other or Unspecified Pattern

ElementDescription: Pattern of Severity: INTERVIEWER: Circle appropriate pattern from descriptions below:
Notes: 1= Episodic Shift; 2= Mild Deterioration; 3= Moderate Deterioration; 4= Severe Deterioration; 5= Relatively Stable
